description: Structured dialogue snippets for financial reasoning, pricing, capital decisions, macro interpretation, and risk framing. Designed for mediator-safe educational responses.

dialogue.line: If we raise prices, won't we lose customers?
Possibly. The real question is elasticity. If demand is relatively inelastic, a moderate increase may improve margin more than it harms volume.
Test incrementally and measure conversion, churn, and net revenue retention before rolling out broadly.
Our revenue is growing, but cash keeps dropping.
Check CAC versus contribution margin. If payback exceeds your cash runway tolerance, growth will strain liquidity.
Sustainable scaling requires LTV meaningfully greater than CAC.
Why does raising interest rates affect my business?
Higher rates increase borrowing costs and can reduce consumer demand. They also compress valuation multiples in capital markets.
Stress test cash flow under slower revenue and higher financing expense.
Should we take debt or raise equity?
Debt preserves ownership but increases fixed obligations. Equity reduces liquidity pressure but dilutes control.
Evaluate stability of cash flows and risk tolerance before choosing.
What is our biggest financial risk?
Liquidity risk under revenue contraction. We are solvent long-term, but short-term cash compression is our vulnerability.
Building a buffer and reducing fixed cost exposure improves resilience.
How will this regulation affect us?
It may increase compliance costs and alter pricing flexibility.
Map the policy to cost structure, demand elasticity, and capital requirements.
What is your LTV to CAC ratio?
Approximately 3.5x with a 9-month payback.
Then focus on retention improvements rather than pure acquisition scale.
